data.title: Nvidia: Accelerating Revenue Growth Into FY2027, Forward P/E Drops To 25x (Upgrade)
data.description:
Why I Upgraded to Buy After 4Q Earnings

NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) has been trading sideways since last summer. Three months ago, the company reported solid Q3 FY2026 earnings, significantly beating all estimates. However, the stock lost upside momentum and has remained flat. Before heading into Q4 FY2026, there were several concerns weighing on the stock's sentiment, including higher input costs, H200 sales in China, fears of AI overspending, increasing competition, and its premium multiple.

In my last 3Q FY2026 analysis, I maintained a Hold rating on NVDA, citing that too much good news had been priced in. When everyone believes that NVDA is a "no-brainer" trade, that overexuberance can become a concern and the stock might take a breather. As we saw, a strong Q3 earnings failed to lift the stock, and a robust Q4 earnings also failed to reignite the hype. The stock briefly popped more than 3% but later reversed all the gains. Some argued that it could be due to higher inventory buildup, while others concern that hyperscalers are building out their own data centers, raising questions about NVDA's long-term growth sustainability.

Nevertheless, the stock's 10 months range-bound move is a de-valuation process, and I believe this process is now complete. The non-GAAP P/E fwd has compressed to 24x, down from 41x in 10 months ago (because non-GAAP forward 12-month EPS consensus has improved significantly while the stock price remained flat). Most importantly, management guided that data center revenue will accelerate on a QoQ basis throughout FY2027, and gross margin will sustain in the mid-70s. Therefore, I believe this Q4 post-earnings pullback could be a buying opportunity.

"Sequential Revenue Growth Throughout Calendar 2026" (FY2027)

Before the Q4 earnings, NVDA had rallied 13% from the February low and is now hovering near all-time highs, so the technical resistance could be hard to break through. It was also likely that investors had already priced in robust Q4 results.

Like prior quarters, the company once again topped all the estimates by a wide margin. As shown in the chart above, Datacenter revenue YoY growth has maintained a "V-shaped" rebound since 2Q FY2026. Considering the 1Q FY2027 midpoint revenue guidance, the total revenue growth will accelerate further to $78 billion, up 77% YoY. I assumed Datacenter revenue will be 90% of its total revenue in 1Q FY2027, which is 30 bps higher than the FY2025 level. This would imply $70.2 billion in Datacenter revenue in 1Q ($78 billion x 90%), or 79% YoY growth.

In the earnings call, CEO Jensen Huang reiterated robust chip demand. He highlighted that the agentic AI inflection has arrived. The company expects "sequential revenue growth throughout calendar 2026, exceeding what was included in the $500 billion Blackwell and Rubin revenue opportunity we shared last year." The Q1 FY2027 revenue outlook suggests a 12.7% QoQ growth. Even assuming a flat 10% sequential growth momentum would imply 70% YoY Datacenter revenue growth for FY2027.

Keep in mind, forward revenue guidance does not assume any revenue from China. Although the U.S government has approved H200 products for China-based customers, the company hasn't generated any sales so far. They are also not sure when these products will be eventually shipped into China.

Gross Margin Concern is Overblown

Recently we've seen a significant price squeeze in HBM and DRAM, up 400% to 500% since September of last year. I was concerned that higher input costs could pressure NVDA's gross margin outlook. However, Q4 FY2026 gross margin continued to expand, driven by increasing Blackwell ramp. Moreover, Q1 FY2027 gross margin is also expected to be resilient at 75%. In the earnings call, management forecasted a "mid-70s" gross margin outlook for FY2027. Based on $7.5 billion non-GAAP operating expenses guidance, we can estimate non-GAAP operating margin will be at 65.4% in Q1, slightly down from 67.7% in the previous quarter.

Increasing Competition from Other Players

First, NVDA remains the top leader in the AI chip market in the near to medium term. with tremendous demand for its Blackwell and Rubin chips. However, investor sentiment could still be impacted by fears of increasing competition.

Earlier this week, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) announced that Meta (META) will buy AMD Instinct GPUs to deploy 6 GW of data center begin in 2H 2026. This news initially sent AMD's stock 9% higher. The company also issued performance-based warrants to META for up to $160 million shares of AMD common stock. The AMD's CEO noted that these warrants would only vest if the stock price reaches $600. In addition, major hyperscalers are also aggressively expanding their data center and design their own AI chips. For example, Google (GOOGL) just raised $500 million to develop chips to directly challenge NVDA's dominance.

The CEO Jensen warned,

"Our competitors in China bolstered by recent IPOs are making progress and have the potential to disrupt the structure of the global AI industry over the long term."

If NVDA can generate additional revenue from H200 sales to China, it would add a revenue tailwind. However, it's unpredictable for now.

Trading at 24.7x of Non-GAAP Forward P/E Now

Due to the relentless rally in 1H 2025, NVDA's valuation was one of my major concerns last year. Back in August 2025, non-GAAP P/E fwd was 41x. Since then, the stock has barely moved. I believe that the current 41x of non-GAAP fwd on the Valuation page has a lag. Based on forward 12-month EPS consensus on the table above (from 1Q FY2027 to 4Q FY2027), NVDA's non-GAAP P/E fwd should be at 24.7x ($196/ $7.94), which justifies an upgrade.

NVDA generated $96.6 billion FCF in FY2026, indicating a 44.6% FCF margin. Assuming a flat FCF margin in FY2027, the company is expected to generate $149 billion in FCF in FY2027. So, its P/FCF fwd is at 31.5x. Compared to these hyperscalers that would have negative FCF next year, NVDA's stock demonstrates much better quality.

Conclusion

In summary, the 4Q FY2026 earnings indicated that robust AI demand continues in CY2026. Datacenter revenue (excluding China) will accelerate further into FY2027. Despite higher input costs, gross margin remains resilient. Although I believe long-term growth sustainability remains a major concern for investors due to raising competition, NVDA's fundamentals show no signs of slowing at this stage. From the valuation perspective, the non-GAAP P/E fwd is at 24.7x, which is a bargain (assuming current forward EPS consensus is reliable). Therefore, I believe it's time to turn bullish on NVDA. and I've upgraded the stock to Buy from Hold.

data.title: Blue, Owl Be Back
data.description:
We have generally had a poor opinion of private equity. Whether it was the investment itself or the managers of private equity, we never really saw the risk-reward as well aligned for our tastes. The main reason behind not wanting to chase either class, came down to valuations. For private equity, it was fairly clear that marking these had usually diverged radically from reality. We saw that in 2022 where tech related private equity mark downs were minimal while the NASDAQ and Invesco QQQ Trust, Series 1 ETF (QQQ) were down over 20%.

That said, not all forms of private and exotic markets carry the same level of risk. There are some like CLO Equity, which have created the worst returns on the spectrum. Funds like Eagle Point Credit Company (ECC) and Oxford Lane Capital (OXLC) have destroyed capital faster than you can say "I am counting my income." On the other hand, Private Credit is generally a lot safer. The reason is that there is usually tons of Private Equity that is standing ahead in line of that same Private Credit.

Blue Owl Capital Inc. (OWL)

We touched upon the recent woes of these private equity/private credit managers in our article, "Bonds Offer Interesting 7.0% Plus Yields". We have also written about OWL and the BDCs it manages in "Blue Owl I Vs. III: Why You Should Give A Hoot". Now, we will get straight into what the current concerns are and why you should still consider taking a position in this company.

1) Data Center Exposure

We have been warning on the ridiculous chase into data centers for some time. In fact, the numbers were so crazy from the perspective of Oracle (ORCL), that we titled that piece, "Suspension Of Disbelief". So if investors are anxious about data centers, we get it. What we don't get is this.

ORCL has absolutely become a conjoined twin with the fate of its data center bet. But OWL is a different beast (bird?) and has a very different level of exposure. Take for example its deal with (META). The $27 billion LLM ( we refuse to use "AI" for regurgitating, hallucinating software) data center deal is where OWL put up $2.5 billion of equity (not debt) and that is where the angst comes from. This was a unique setup that made the debt of the project (backed by PIMCO and Blackstone) safe, while OWL stands first in line to deal with the bubble fallout.

The debt priced at +225 bps over Treasuries, roughly double the spread on Meta’s own corporate bonds. Yet for insurance investors, the yield looks attractive. They get Meta’s implied credit strength thanks to the RVG, which guarantees the project’s residual value for 16 years without the correlation risk of owning Meta equity.

That guarantee, according to S&P, was “the linchpin” that earned the debt its A+ rating. It effectively transfers technology-obsolescence risk (the danger that AI chips age faster than the building) back to Meta.

Source: S&P Global

The reason that the debt earns an A+ rating is because META can walk away 4 years after it is operational, but it guarantees a minimum residual value that makes the debt holders, whole. But OWL is not a debt holder here and there in lies the concern. All that said, we find this obsession with OWL's equity funding as rather strange. That is because OWL is NOT funding it. The funds underlying OWL's investment management arm are funding it. The $2.5 billion of equity should be compared to the total AUM, which is now over $300 billion ($185 billion if you count only fee bearing capital). In return for this, the funds likely earn mid-teens return on equity. OWL has other data center deals in place, but again, these are funded from the underlying funds and make up a fraction of the total AUM. Yes, losses can occur, but these deals are not exactly "collecting pennies in front of a steamroller".

2) SAAS Exposure

Of course, that is not all there is to the OWL news. The SAAS (software as a stop-loss, or something like that) exposure has gotten the attention of the market as well. We discussed this more in depth with the members of our service, and we won't go into all the points here. But suffice to say, we believe the odds of Claude doing a massive software displacement line up with what everyone believed about Upstart (UPST)'s "AI" and displacement of Fair Isaac Corporation (FICO) and their scores in 2021. From the peak of that insanity, here are the returns for both.

3) Redemption Halt

Yes OWL did stop redemptions on one of its funds.

While that may sound terrifying, not every asset has the liquidity of the US Treasury market. If you had a fund, which invested in Class A apartment buildings and you had to liquidate them, there is almost no way you could do that overnight without losing a lot of spread. Private credit is a far more complicated investment and anyone buying this debt of any single investment would have to do a lot of due diligence. It isn't really designed to be sold as needed for redemptions. Stopping the liquidation process is actually the best move and prevents unnecessary losses. If investors wanted the liquidity of public markets, well, they should have stayed in public markets. We think order will be restored down the line and let's keep in mind that even this fund makes up less than 1% of OWL's AUM.

Verdict

Yes, things might go bad for private credit at some point. If that is the argument and people want to stay away, that's ok. We think private credit is well-priced and designed for good returns. It is certainly beautifully priced relative to the S&P 500 (SPY). So we think this is a good time to invest a measured amount here. We did initiate OWL covered calls the other day and they have fairly attractive returns for a flattish price.

We also pointed out to our subscribers that the solid debt of OWL was trading at a near 7% yield to maturity. That is an interesting option for defensive investors as well. OWL's credit rating is excellent:

We have personally traded the bonds before, but this time we just went with covered calls as the return profile was much better.

Please note that this is not financial advice. It may seem like it sounds like it, but surprisingly, it is not. Investors are expected to do their own due diligence and consult a professional who knows their objectives and constraints. Most of our articles are not written for “buy and hold” investors. Our articles are not written for investors who ignore capital preservation while focusing only on yield.

data.title: Oil States International: Don't Trip Over That Hockey Stick!
data.description:
Introduction

You would think after 8 years of writing on this platform that I would have covered every company in the upstream space. Two or three times. Sadly, that's just not the case; new names still bubble up to the surface. In this outing, we add Oil States International (OIS) to the coverage universe.

Good golly, it's been a while since I've seen a hockey stick graph like the one below. The company has made a parabolic move higher, following its earnings release last week and after SCOTUS struck down Trump's use of IEEPA tariffs that had raised tariffs on some of their key products to 98%! And to continue with another 16% gain over a couple of days when most of the rest of the OSF category was giving back? That's intriguing, to say the least.

Oil States is a key supplier to the offshore rig market. When rigs are cranking, so too is OIS. The company graphic below gives you an idea of their spectrum of product offerings. You can certainly see the relationship to floating structures, even if the specific application doesn't mean a lot. We will go into a bit of detail on some of them a bit more a little later.

OIS is a market leader in several categories and has invested in new facilities in the UK and Indonesia that give it an advantage in an improving market. It is also introducing new technologies to replace older, land-based offerings that have seen declines along with the rig count.

The company turned in a big beat on EPS of $0.13 vs. $0.10 for Q4 2026, while missing on the topline by $454K. Analysts rate the company as an overweight with price targets as high as $15.00. The median is $13.50-where they trade now at the apogee of the parabola. This also constitutes a 5-year high for the stock, so we will tread carefully on this one.

The business case for Oil States

One sign that an increase in offshore activity is coming is the book-to-bill ratio for OIS. At 1.3X, it has reached the highest level in a decade. Much of this is from offshore rig upgrades and reactivations, but also from newer product offerings like their Managed Pressure Drilling—MPD, Perforating, and Mineral Riser. The company is optimistic they have turned a corner, particularly as regards international and offshore-related projects. While we agree that the offshore industry is on an upswing, it should also be noted there are capacity limits to this increase on the deepwater side. We have what we have in floating inventory, and no one is building new units. So it's ok to be optimistic-I am—but let's keep our feet on the ground. This is not 2005. There is no oil boom coming.

OIS has three primary operating segments: Offshore Manufactured Products, Completion and Production Services, and Downhole Technologies.

Cindy Taylor, CEO, commented about the upgrade cycle now underway-

We're beginning to see those white spaces, gaps be filled in. And so rig equipment will tend to lead the recovery, and that can be riser systems, MPD systems for us, the things that we offer as well as kind of the upgrade and service cycle around that equipment, but it all feeds deepwater infrastructure, which, again, that's kind of a bread and butter for us that plays into our more proprietary products.

Catalyst for Oil States

Have you ever tried to use a long pole-something 12-15' long—to wash off a spot on the eaves of your house? If you have, you likely experienced a problem common to landing out a marine riser thousands of feet below the rig floor-getting the thing to be in the position you need it to be in. Once you've overcome mechanical flexing, submarine currents, and the occasional shark (as you see below from a job I worked for BP in the GoM. Once we saw the shark, we suspended operations and allowed the critter to satisfy its curiosity. It took about half an hour, but he eventually swam away into the inky-it's really dark at 3,400 below MSL, depths and we got back to work.) That's curious about what you're doing, and you have it in a stabbing position-verified by your robotic camera flyby controlled by a tether from the rig's deck.

You want it to snap in cleanly and make the connection. Making a long story short, it doesn't always happen, and non-productive time-NPT results. Oil companies hate this and will reward companies that enable smooth operations with contracts. That appears to be the case with the OIS Flexjoint connector. The Flexjoint enables the riser to withstand currents and maintain its connection to the subsea BOP by flexing with the force. (You do not want to imagine the misery that follows an unplanned disconnect-it's bad, really bad.) Having this leading position in Flexjoint connectors is a distinct advantage for OIS.

Managed Pressure Drilling-MPD is an interesting growth area for OIS. The segment is well covered by legacy multi-service OFS companies-Big Red. Big Blue. Big Aqua and others. They don't give a lot of information about it in the filing but commented favorably on the early results in the conference call.

OIS also has offerings in perforating that appear to be gaining success-in a fairly crowded marketplace. Here again the big colors hold the biggest chunks of this business. The company cited international opportunities as driving their optimism in this area.

In summary, OIS is a legacy supplier to the offshore industry with an excellent reputation in their core offerings. When companies like Transocean (RIG) talk about upgrade and reactivation capex, they very often are talking about money that will end up on OIS' income statement. From my experience, I can tell that when a client trusts your core offerings, it makes it much easier to get field trials for new technology.

OIS Q4 Earning Call

OIS reported revenues of $178 million, up 8% sequentially from the third quarter. Profitability also improved with adjusted EBITDA of $23 million, representing a 9% sequential increase. Non-cash impairments on long-lived assets led to a loss of $117 mm. This was related to valuation declared on the 2018 acquisition in their Downhole Technology segment.

OIS generated 63% greater positive cash flow of $50 mm for the quarter than previously and 129% greater $105 mm for the year. Free cash of $94 mm was reported, a 92% rise YoY.

Their largest segment, Offshore Manufactured Products generated revenues of $123 million and EBITDA of $25 mm at a 20% margin. Backlog for this segment was reported at $435 mm. Completion Products turned in $23 mm in revenues and $7 mm in EBITDA with an operating margin of 32%. Restructuring charges of $5 mm were noted for the segment. Downhole Technologies reported revenues of $32 mm with EBITDA of $1.3 mm-impacted by segment impairments.

OIS has a new 4-year cash flow-based credit agreement, which provides for borrowings of up to $75 million. This is under a revolving credit facility that replaced their asset-based lending credit agreement. OIS has $53 million of convertible senior notes outstanding at December 31. The plan is to use U.S. cash on hand and tap their new revolver to retire these notes prior to their maturity on April 1, 2026.

At YE 2025, OIS had $15 mm in cash on hand, had retired $71 mm in senior notes during the year, and repurchased $17 mm in stock during 2025.

Guidance for 2026

OIS expects 2026 full-year revenues to range between $680 million and $700 million, up about 5% YoY. Full-year EBITDA should range between $90 million and $95 million, nearly double 2025. Q-1 should see revenues in a range of $150 million to $155 million and EBITDA of $18 million to $19 million.

Strong cash flows from operations are expected for the year. With a range of $60 million to $65 million, down from 2025 due to expected working capital builds. Investments in CapEx of $20 million to $25 million are planned for the year.

Company filings

Risks

The offshore comeback has been a bit of a 'fits and starts' operation over the past couple of years. Signs are that it is accelerating all around, but further delays could impact OIS revenues and cash flows. The parabolic move higher over the past few days is concerning, as it's related more to implied tariff relief than an improvement in core business fundamentals. We haven't had the last word on tariffs yet, so there may be other shoes to drop.

Your takeaway

I think a lot of near-term growth is priced into OIS at current levels. As shown below, the company is trading far in excess of its peer group's EV/EBITDA on a TTM basis. On an NTM basis, they are more reasonable at 7.77X if they hit their revenue and EBITDA targets of $700 mm and $95 mm respectively, so let's use those numbers to estimate a closer valuation for the shares. OIS has essentially no LT debt, so with 58 mm shares outstanding and $95 mm in EBITDA 7.77X, you get a share price of $12.72.

If I were long, I would sell at current levels to protect the substantial gains made over a very short period of time. Accordingly, I rate OIS a sell at current levels, in spite of their excellent prospects in the year to come. If they revert to their January 2026 levels of $7-8.00 per share, I would look hard at taking a position for measured growth that will surely come if the offshore renaissance becomes a reality.

data.title: Crescent Energy: A Royal Addition
data.description:
Crescent Energy (CRGY) has actually acquired significant midstream assets along the way. But now there is an obvious attempt to also gain royalty interests at a good price. Diversification into these two areas can help with company performance during cyclical downturns. Creating a separate royalty company as others have done can also help to finance transactions. It is yet another interest in production profits that can aid a lower breakeven.

In the meantime, the dominate upstream interests in the Eagle Ford and the Permian should provide above average profitability for a management that generally builds and sells companies. There are alot improvements to be made (as well be discussed in this article) that benefit royalties as well.

This is a management that pays a lot of attention to the cash flow statement. Not only should cash flow grow, but cash flow per share should grow as well. This company made 3 significant acquisitions in fiscal year 2025. That type of activity is going to make it very hard for investors to see the progress made for the properties already owned. It also makes the quarterly report next to useless.

However, as the company grows larger, the acquisitions will become less significant (as a percentage of the company). What should happen over time is that operational improvements will dominate. This is a company that will very likely be concentrating on cash flow and free cash flow.

Professionals that build companies know that cash generation is the key to getting a good price when the right time comes to sell the company. Right now, this company is clearly in buying mode. That should tell investors, that the industry overall is likely cheap (and out of favor). When management like this one decides to sell the company, that will be the time for most of us to consider cutting back our presence investing in oil and gas to wait for the next favorable time to get in.

Last Article

The last article noted that the company closed the acquisition of Vital Energy. The current announcement notes that Vital Energy was only part of the company for a few days of the quarter.

But that means that because of this rather significant acquisition, the company is going to be showing considerable production growth in the present fiscal year (2026).

Now that the company has acquired the assets, there is an update to the potential synergy savings. Fortunately, it is on the upward revisions side. More importantly, the rig activity has been sharply reduced.

As has been mentioned in many articles here, KKR is the manager of this company. Free cash flow is a very big deal to KKR. As the company gets larger and the financial statements are not clouded with lots of one-time items, this emphasis on free cash flow (growth) is likely to present itself first.

The Vital Energy acquisition was by far the largest acquisition of the fiscal year. At issue here is things like stock dilution (and debt) come first with the benefits likely showing in fiscal year 2026.

The company is showing investors where those benefits will come from. But this acquisition also provides the company with an entry into a second very low-cost basin.

At the same time, as part of a larger company, "in-housing" some of the operations that were contracted out is a very big deal. Vital Energy had begun some of the operational improvements noted above before the acquisition. But it had not owned much of the Permian properties itself for all that long.

As a much larger company (post combination) Crescent Energy is able to probably get better prices for the production than Vital could.

However, both companies had to live with existing production costs to some extent because the previous operators were likely high cost. Those high costs can be dealt with to some extent. But largely, that older production simply declines in significance as production declines. It will be replaced by lower cost production. But in terms of operating costs declining, that is a weighted average process that will take some time for the new lower well costs to gain significance.

Eagle Ford

The Eagle Ford assets have largely been a part of the company for a year. There was a large Eagle Ford acquisition of less than $1 billion that closed at the beginning of fiscal year 2025. That was really the only addition to these assets of a significant size.

This is the place where the savings will become apparent first because these assets are the oldest assets (for the most part) in the portfolio. This is also where most of the company production is presently. Future acquisitions could change that now that the company has a presence in the Permian.

Probably the biggest surprise is the natural gas position that is so close to export capability and may also be sold in the future to data centers as well. This was an upside that many of us did not see on the horizon at the time this company began operations. Now it is a big deal.

Debt

This company has received one debt rating upgrade since it went public. There is a goal here to get to investment grade.

As noted above, things are going to definitely improve because of that goal of an investment grade rating. If the improvements shown before (and probably a few more I did not show) actually materially improve things, then that will change the debt rating fraction numerator.

This company is also faster than most to sell noncore acreage to raise cash. Probably one of the best debt managers in the business is KKR. This is what is going to make the cash flow statement the most important statement in the future.

Summary

Crescent Energy did post a loss for the quarter as there was an impairment charge combined with a lot of transaction costs that were a part of the Vital Energy acquisition closing.

What as more important is that cash flow grew significantly for the fiscal year while the debt ratio stayed within range for the company to still go for an investment grade debt rating.

As long as this company is making acquisitions, that likely means that acquisition prices are attractive (and the industry remains relatively out of favor).

That makes this idea a long-term idea with the idea that the company will be built during times of attractive acquisition prices. It will be sold when prices are cyclically strong. But that means investors need to wait patiently for the time when selling prices are attractive enough to sell the company.

This is a strong buy idea in that rarely do investors get the chance to invest alongside KKR and John Goff. That does mean success is guaranteed. But it does put the odds in favor of the investment idea succeeding. This part has not changed since the company went public.

I would probably hang on to this idea until the company gets sold.

Risks

Even with investors like KKR and John Goff, an investment idea can fail to work out for any number of reasons. However, there is a safety factor here in that the debt ratio is within a reasonable range. Companies with relatively low debt rarely get into serious trouble. There is every chance here that with the project improvements to acquired properties, that debt ratio will decline even if no money was used to repay debt.

Any acquisition can fail to meet expectations. On the other side of that both John Goff and KKR have made many acquisitions (to have a whole lot of experience making acquisitions).

KKR is used to building and selling companies. That lowers the risk of fast growth. Fast growth has the risk of losing quality control and cost overruns. So, the experience is needed to minimize some potentially serious issues.

It is extremely difficult to tell much of anything from the financial statements when a company is constantly making acquisitions. But that makes the investor evaluation of management very important to the success of the investment. At this point we are very much dependent upon management representations to tell the progress made. Debt ratings help as well.

data.title: RingCentral: Expansion Of Profitability Continues
data.description:
We last wrote about RingCentral (RNG) following the earnings report for the previous quarter. Since then, its shares have jumped by 21% compared with a little-changed S&P 500. We are confident that the key driver behind the price spike in the wake of the report (with prices surging by more than 30% at one point) was a short squeeze, as short interest exceeded 11% at the time.

Furthermore, the positive reaction and the flushing out of short positions were presumably triggered by high profitability driven by operating leverage—which is exactly what we wagered on in our previous note on the company.

Let's look at 4Q 2025 numbers

- Revenue climbed by 4.8% y/y to $644 mln, which was $518k above SA consensus;

- EBITDA jumped by 39.5% y/y to $98.6 mln. We calculate EBITDA as operating income + D&A;

The company also delivered a third straight quarter with a positive GAAP net income (total GAAP net income for FY2025 is $43.4 mln).

Operating metrics

- Subscriptions revenue increased by 6% y/y to $622 mln;

- ARR went up by 7% y/y to $2.7 bln, outpacing revenue growth.

Management’s guidance

Subscription revenue is seen rising by 4.5%–5.5% in 2026, with total revenue climbing by 4%–5%. This indicates that the growth of subscriptions revenue is expected to slow relative to 2025 (which was 5.6%). As a note, we had expected revenue growth to accelerate in 2026, driven by faster growth in AI products and better ARR retention. FCF is set to total $580–$600 mln. FWD FCF yield is seen reaching more than 20% using current market cap. GAAP operating margin is seen at 8.6%-9.6% (almost doubling from FY2025 level).

Interpreting the earnings report

Reported revenue topped expectations, and EPS roughly met consensus expectations. It is worth noting the company only recently reached operating profitability, so the metric remains volatile. Still, a trend toward faster growth in profitability is evident and is reflected in very robust FCF forecasts. FCF for 2025 totaled $530 mln, hitting the upper end of management guidance. For 2026, the metric is projected to rise by another 12.2% at the midpoint.

Shares shot up by 30%+ above $40 on the heels of the report (later correcting to $35). We believe this was likely driven by a faster-than-expected profitability growth and the fact that AI does not yet pose a critical threat to the business. These reasons probably triggered a short squeeze. Additionally, the company announced its first-ever quarterly dividend, set at $0.075 per share, translating into an annual yield of approximately 1%.

Our take on the report is mixed. On one hand, we see a solid track record in FCF and net income, which is typically achieved through operating expense optimization.

On the other hand, management’s revenue guidance came in lower than our estimate. We had projected an acceleration in 2026 on the back of higher ARR retention. To be fair, the 4Q retention rate technically outperformed our forecast (we had expected 99.3%, matching the prior quarter, while the actual figure was almost 100%). Therefore, there is a chance that RingCentral could still succeed in accelerating its revenue growth. There are several conditions for this:

1) The combined ARR of new AI products reached $100 mln (~4% of total ARR), as the management expected previously;

2) There’s continued rapid growth in new products. AIR (AI Receptionist) is the fastest-growing product with 8,300+ customers, up 40%+ q/q. The model is based on minute usage, which mitigates the impact from seat reductions. ACE has 4,800+ customers, up 144% y/y. RingCX has 1,500+ customers, nearly doubling y/y. More than 50% of large deals ($1 mln+ TCV) include RingCX;

3) The proportion of ARR from customers that utilize at least one monetized AI product reached 10%. This is a new metric tracked by RingCentral. It is noted that the retention rate for these customers exceeds 100%.

Given everything mentioned above, management’s revenue guidance feels like a fly in the ointment. In terms of profitability momentum, our assumptions remain intact. As for revenue, the projected 4.5%–5.5% for the subscription segment implies a midpoint of 5%. This is below the growth of the addressable market (5.3% annually according to our initial coverage statistics), which we track. Consequently, management’s outlook implies that the company could begin losing market share in 2026 and that AI products will not have a significant impact on the general momentum, which runs counter to our expectations. But so far, RingCentral’s subscription revenue has been rising with a positive beta to the market. Even so, we are not changing our expectations for the company at this time and are maintaining our existing 2026 forecasts, keeping both our target price and BUY rating.

We are maintaining the EBITDA forecast for 2026 at $401 mln (+22.5% y/y).

We are maintaining the target price at $67. We are also maintaining the rating at BUY.

Over the coming quarters, we will also monitor subscription revenue and ARR to see if the market share shrinks. In the event that growth does slow, we will revise our forecast downward. However, the valuation has a wide margin of safety due to high profitability and FCF yield, which implies that a BUY rating will likely remain in place even if the valuation is revised downward.

Bottomline

RingCentral continues to demonstrate strong profitability momentum and robust free cash flow generation, supporting our positive long-term view. However, management’s 2026 revenue guidance raises concerns about potential market share pressure and slower top-line acceleration than we had anticipated. But we still believe the company is capable of beating management's guidance. For now, we maintain our BUY rating and $67 target price, given the company’s solid FCF yield and improving operating leverage.

data.title: Comfort Systems: Another Infrastructure Superstar, A Stock Well Worth Its High Valuation
data.description:
Oh my. Another one!

On 2/24/26, I published a report on Hubbell (HUBB). My “Buy” recommendation characterized it as a “strong capital allocator.” I even went so far as to suggest a Warren Buffett comparison.

HUBB wasn’t a one-off. There are several great companies in this field. So, I’ve long been bullish on infrastructure stocks.

But I haven’t been impressed with the portfolios of thematic ETFs like Global X US Infrastructure Development ETF (PAVE) that supposedly specialize in this area.

The funds performed well. But as I found too often with thematic ETFs, many of the names in the portfolios didn’t match the kinds I consider truly representative of the stated theme. For example…

  • The 1/31/26 top ten holdings of PAVE, the largest such ETF by assets, included Howmet Aerospace (HWM) and railroads Norfolk Southern (NS) and CSX (CSX).
  • The next largest peer (as per what’s shown as such on Seeking Alpha) is the FlexShares STOXX Global Broad Infrastructure Index ETF (NFRA). Its 1/31/26 top ten included Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), Softbank (SFTBY), Verizon (VZ), AT&T (T), Canadian Pacific Kansas City (CP), and Canadian National (CNI).

I was similarly unhappy with other infrastructure ETFs. I suppose everybody gets to define infrastructure their own way.

But I wish I could find an ETF issuer that defines it as I wish—the physical plant of the U.S. To me, that includes industrial buildings, highways, government facilities, etc. Lately, tech-related facilities have become a larger part of the mix. I’m referring, here, to chip manufacturing and data centers.

So, I’ve been ignoring the infrastructure ETFs. Instead, I’ve been finding and writing about individual companies that appeal to me.

As a long-time devotee of fundamental stock screening, this turned out to have been an easy task. These companies often have excellent fundamentals. So, they’ve been bubbling up to the top of my screening/ranking results for the last several years.

Most have been in the Construction and Engineering industry. A few, including HUBB, are classified as Electrical Components and Equipment.

All such companies I profiled on Seeking Alpha (see below) have been pretty good capital allocators. But HUBB seemed to be a cut above this already strong group.

And then, I studied up on Comfort Systems (FIX). It beats HUBB. In fact, to summarize my views on FIX’s fundamental and capital allocation prowess, I’ll offer one word – Wow!

At this point in my Seeking Alpha write-ups, I usually introduce and discuss company business topics. Then, I move on to present the key numbers.

But FIX has impressed this long-time quant as being so amazing, it seems appropriate, here, to reverse my usual sequence and start with the data.

FIX’s Numbers

Let's begin with the quarterly revenue and EPS trends.

Here are the year-to-year percent changes.

I assume you noticed the lesser 2027 comparisons.

Don’t worry.

Surely, you’ve heard of Benjamin Franklin’s memorable articulation of life’s two great certainties, death and taxes. Had he lived today, I think he would have added a third, estimate revision. There are good reasons why Seeking Alpha offers us information tracking this.

Here are the annual revision trends for FIX.

When we get to the business below, you’ll see why I don’t take FIX’s 2027 estimates seriously. I expect they, like previously published estimates, will eventually be raised.

Let’s now move on to the comparative data I usually present.

As you know if you’re familiar with my work, I compare companies to industry medians and medians for companies in the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY) portfolio. (I use medians since these aren’t impacted by wild distortions often caused by unusual data items.)

Here, I added another comparative benchmark I labeled Peer.

The latter consists of other infrastructure companies I’ve covered on Seeking Alpha. (It doesn’t yet include FIX. I’ll add it after this report is published.)

  • Dycom Industries (DY) – my latest report
  • EMCOR Group (EME) – my latest report
  • Hubbell (HUBB) – my latest report
  • MasTec (MTZ) – my latest report
  • MYR Group (MYRG) – my latest report
  • nVent Electric (NVT) – my latest report
  • Powell Industries (POWL) – my latest report
  • Quanta Services – my latest report
  • Sterling Infrastructure (STRL) – my latest report

(HUBB, NVT, and POWL are Electrical Components and Equipment companies. The others are Construction and Engineering.)

The following comparative tables won’t require explanation. FIX will beat the daylights out of the SPY, and the Construction and Engineering medians.

Interestingly, it’ll also beat, across the board, the already strong Peer medians.

Finally, here are the Financial Statement Highlights.

This table, too, speaks for itself. Notice…

  • Strong and up-trending gross and operating margins,
  • Soaring cash balances,
  • Declining ratio of long-term debt to total capital,
  • Modest capital spending needs (a capital-light business),
  • Capital allocation flexibility that lets FIX choose among bigger dividends, acquisition and share buybacks, and…
  • Tiny stock compensation expense (contributing to strong earnings quality).

Numerically speaking, to repeat what I said above — Wow!

But I couldn’t and wouldn’t speak glowingly about the data unless I was convinced that they flowed naturally and sustainably from…

The Business — How FIX Generates Those Numbers

This was and still is a very straightforward endeavor.

FIX is a subcontractor that participates in the construction of non-residential buildings. Traditionally, it handled HVAC systems. Over time, FIX also added piping, plumbing, and electrical work.

Cue, now, material I’ve added to some past reports discussing Peter Lynch extolling the virtues of being dull. In sum, boring companies attract little investment community attention or hype and, therefore, give investors opportunities to buy before the shares move up.

To conserve word count, I’ll put on my legal hat and use some court lingo: With respect to dull stock content in this write-up, I repeat, reiterate, and re-allege all such verbiage as if set forth more fully herein.

Of course, if this was really an adversarial court case, opposing counsel might object pointing out that FIX’s valuations (see below) don’t look like what we’d expect from a dull company that excites nobody.

The answer (ruling): Sometimes dull companies serve exciting customers, and this causes even Monotony Inc. to generate too much growth even for sexy-story-loving Mr. Market to completely ignore.

Given FIX’s past share price performance and current valuation, I’d completely understand if one might say “the time to buy was back… whenever.” We can say likewise for many other stocks—Nvidia (NVDA), Alphabet (GOOGL), etc., etc., etc.

The key to FIX, and all such situations, is how the company stands now. Does its present situation suggest better times ahead?

For FIX, I say “yes.” The factors that contributed to its past success remain active…

Acquisitions

Like most of the infrastructure companies I favor, FIX has been a serial acquirer (and expects to remain so going forward). That’s definitely been a factor in its growth. And even though these acquisitions have largely been accretive, they have not been merely financial…

They’ve been operationally strategic. And they’ve made FIX a more serious player in terms of electrical construction.

FIX’s corporate evolution accomplished two things.

First, it led to FIX dramatically boosting diversification. It now serves many different aspects of construction and engineering.

And areas into which FIX has been expanding have been faster growing. (That’s how it got into data centers.)

Notice, in the segment breakdowns below, how rapidly the Electrical group is growing. (Notice too how the Manufacturing segment is also pretty good.)

But it takes more than just this to generate the kinds of results we’ve seen for FIX. So, let’s continue…

People

Countless CEOs wax poetic about how great the company’s people are. I’ve heard enough of these praise orgies to brush most of them off as corporate puffery.

But sometimes, it seems sensible to pay more attention.

FIX is a capital-light people business. Its so-called assets are the relationships it has with the many tradespeople craft professionals, who work on its projects.

We often hear talk of shortages of skilled labor, due to things like retirements of baby boomers, and fewer young people choosing to enter into the trades. So obviously, paying well will help FIX attracting a good workforce.

But more is needed. And indeed, we saw above in the Financial Statement Highlights that FIX isn’t exactly crushing its own margins by overpaying.

Work conditions and terms of employment are also important.

CFO Trent McKenna said at the 12/11/25 Sidoti virtual conference:

[L]ong-term thinking, as you think about, okay, the value of Comfort Systems, it really is embedded in its ability to be the place where we're the best place where a craft professional wants to build a career. And we have some advantages from that because of our scale and also our ability to kind of manage the locality and the localness of a business so that a craft professional wants to be part of that business, while at the same time benefiting from the scale of Comfort Systems.

Going further, he added…

[I]n the craft professional world, you have a labor that wants to stay within about 100 miles of their home. And that's how they like to do it. And then you have a labor that wants to travel, wants to go somewhere and spend 4 to 6 months working on a project and then go back to where they call home. So those 2 people, we needed to supplement comfort systems on the traveler side. So that was why we brought in Kodiak, and they've been really helpful in helping us flex into all this demand and be able to meet the requirements that our customers have.

(Kodiak, a construction-oriented staffing company, is an interesting example of a FIX strategic acquisition!)

Management pointed out that it usually gets so many job opportunities, it’s able to be picky, to choose those it deems the best.

That has a direct impact on its people. Later in the conference, Chief Accounting Officer Julie Shaeff said…

[P]rice is an important factor when we look at projects, but it's not everything. And what we really are looking for is project work that's really good for our employees that our employees are happy to work on that they are -- it's going to be safe. It's in a good geography. It's easy to get to. It's -- the projects -- we think we'll have a good chance of being executed well…. But I also think it's been -- the fact that we've been able to pick the work we're on has contributed to those good outcomes.

So, is this real or is it puffery? We can each form our own opinion. For me, based on financial performance that’s consistent with all this, I believe it’s real.

Margins

Look again at the above Financial Statement Highlights table.

How ‘bout those margin trends!

As noted above, FIX isn’t likely overpaying to attract people. But the operational results it's achieving suggest FIX isn’t underpaying to boost margins either.

The answer, I believe, lies in thoughtful productivity enhancement.

That’s the best way I can think of to boost margins!

Innovation

Have you seen my 2/3/26 Cavco (CVCO) writeup?

If not, I suggest checking it out. CVCO is known for factory-built housing. I think that can play a major role in addressing our housing shortage and affordability problems—assuming consumers are able to afford anything and assuming localities can get beyond that industry’s trailer-park image.

I point it out here because FIX is doing an industrial version of this same thing—modular building.

It offers cost benefits equivalent to what CVCO offers to home buyers. But in the industrial market, FIX is not burdened by CVCO-style customer affordability or resistance due to image obstacles

FIX, probably to the envy of firms like CVCO, is playing to a very receptive audience. So the business is growing briskly.

On the 2/20/26 earnings call, CEO Brian Lane told analysts

Our modular capacity is currently around 3 million square feet, and we expect to increase this to approximately 4 million square feet by the end of 2026, with planned additions in Texas and North Carolina.

Later during the call, Mckenna added:

More than 1/2 our sequential backlog increase was new modular bookings and with the continuing increase in modular and larger project backlog, the duration of our backlog continues to extend. Since last year, our backlog has doubled with an increase of $6 billion on a same -- and on a same-store basis, our backlog is 93% higher than at this time last year.

Speaking of backlog, let’s pivot now to…

Earnings Prospects

Because past performance does not determine future outcomes, none of the historical numbers I presented above would mean anything unless we have reason to expect the favorable trends to persist into the future.

The backlog (in which modular buildings figure prominently) suggests FIX is more likely gathering speed than decelerating.

That makes sense given the businesses to which FIX is exposed.

That’s like a who’s who of growing businesses.

Onshoring in general, whether based on nationalistic politics or renewed appreciation of the more easily manageable domestic supply chains has become pretty compelling. And it's stimulating increased U.S. capital investment in semiconductors. And of course there’s AI and data centers.

Meanwhile, here’s a still small but potentially interesting stealth (my label) trend.

As FIX does more and more construction work, opportunities grow for it to add new service-maintenance clients.

This would mean a growing base of recurring revenues. Many companies would see that as the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. And every year brings FIX further along that path.

Meanwhile, let’s not forget acquisitions. FIX is likely to keep expanding this way.

All in all, there are good reasons to expect FIX to remain fundamentally strong in the future.

And it seems that the 2027 estimates shown above are every bit as likely as past estimates to be revised upward.

Risk

One form of risk is present not just for FIX but for all companies, especially those owned by growth investors. I’m referring to earnings-related sentiment.

FIX has a track record of upward estimate revisions. But if FIX disappoints in the future, the stock could suffer.

Remember, too, this could hit the stock even if FIX continues to perform great. What counts nowadays isn’t how well FIX does. It’s how well FIX performs relative to analyst expectations.

And there’s the big business risk—data centers. Is there a building bubble? (There’s also risk pertaining to industrial construction in general.) But for now, that’s likely being dwarfed by data-center bubble risk.)

I disagree with the bubble talk.

I’ve extensively discussed this very recently in connection with some of FIX’s peers. I won’t repeat it all now. You can see my thoughts here and here.

But today, I would like to bring in an intriguing new wrinkle—fears that AI will badly disrupt software, among other things.

Here’s an interesting article on the topic from Seeking Alpha REIT expert Jussi Askola, CFA. He discusses a wide range of endeavors. And he suggests how badly AI can hurt them.

I’m not suggesting you agree or disagree with him. Speaking for myself, I. think he’s partly right. I believe AI will change things, but not destroy them.

Consider software. Have you ever tried to program anything, even an Excel macro? If so, you know the make-or-break issue is in the logic.

Professionals create flow charts. Dilettantes like me use pseudocode (plain-English statements in lieu of statements or commands that conform to a particular programming language).

AI can and is creating the correct programming syntax. But where do you think the goals and logic come from? If you access Claude’s coding features, how do you start?

Somewhere along the line, a human has to prompt AI. And how much might that prompt engineering have to resemble what, say, a Python developer must do to get going?

If you don’t believe me, open Claude (or Gemini or ChatGPT or Grok or anything) and consider what you, the human, must do before AI can do anything!

So again, I see AI as a catalyst for change, and possibly even disruption. But I don’t see it as a destroyer.

Now, here’s the punch line…

How on earth can we even imagine anything remotely like AI eating software and other industries unless we wind up with a humongous amount of new data center capacity!

Logic mandates that we can’t have it both ways.

One can’t dump data center plays because we won’t need all these facilities and, at the same time, dump software giants like Salesforce (CRM), CrowdStrike (CRWD), etc., because AI will take over their businesses.

At some point, we and Mr. Market will have to pick a lane.

As I tend to do on wide highways, I prefer middle lane. (I shun the sloths who can drive you crazy in the right lane and the speed demons who terrorize the left lane.)

In this context, it means seeing software and other companies as survivors, albeit after having evolved, and seeing AI and data centers as having long runways, as discussed here and here.

In sum, the only bubble I see bursting is the excess of self-congratulatory and often mocking in tone bearish AI rhetoric.

What To Do About FIX Stock

Here are FIX’s valuation ratios.

Yes, the P/E FWD and EV/S ratios are high.

Think of ratios like that as sticker prices like what you see everywhere else. How much you’re willing to pay depends on what you expect to get. Surely you can’t imagine you’d get a new Toll Brothers (TOL) luxury home for the same price Cavco (CVCO) charges for its factory-built homes!

In the stock market, the what you expect to get is measured by expected future growth (EPS for P/E FWD and sales for EV/S), and by company quality.

The table shows us FIX offers prospects for ample growth. And FIX’s PEG FWD is low enough that it could still remain attractive relative to benchmarks even if the Proj. 3-5Y EPS GR doesn’t fully live up to the current expectation.

And as I discussed in connection with HUBB on 2/24/26, don’t forget to consider quality. (Many folks miss this element of valuation. If you’re into quant modeling, higher quality/lower business risk mandates the use of lower discount rates. That pushes P/E and EV/S upward—see here.) Now, look above at the FIX core fundamentals and financial statement highlights tables. Those show FIX as being a very high-quality company.

So, I believe FIX shares are well worth the current valuation.

The price chart suggests Mr. Market agrees.

That’s a great chart.

The 10-day exponential moving average (EMA) is above the 50-day EMA. And both are still climbing. We’re not looking at a rocket ship. I’d prefer to label this as gentle momentum.

Consider, too, Chaikin Money Flow (CMF) and the Chaikin Oscillator (CO). Both measure which party to trades is more motivated. CMF does it for institutional investors. CO does it for the market in general.

Both indicators have been spending a lot of time comfortably ensconced in bullish territory. That suggests upward pressure on stock prices.

When it comes to rating stocks, I think in terms of probable future stock performance relative to the market, rather than literally buying, holding, or selling.

And since I’m not rating based on a quant model, I’ll eschew “Strong …” extremes. Absent an exceptional degree of conviction, I think “Buy,” Hold,” or “Sell” are enough.

As discussed above, it’s easy to look at the chart and mourn one’s having not bought into FIX “back on….”

But that’s a never-ending, go-nowhere exercise; we can drive ourselves crazy applying to any stocks. I don’t suggest getting wrapped up in that.

Looking ahead, the only direction in which we can look...

I see FIX as likely continuing to outperform the broader market.

I translate that to the Seeking Alpha rating taxonomy by rating FIX as a “Buy.”

data.title: Circle Q4 Earnings: Is USDC The Winner In The Crypto Winter?
data.description:
After a 35% jump in its share price after reporting Q4 results, Circle Internet Group, Inc. (CRCL) is back on the radar.

I see a company at the intersection of two forces reshaping modern finance. The bulls are looking at the migration of dollars into blockchains, with USDC seen as a main beneficiary. The bears are put off by the recurring swings in the crypto space between risk-on exuberance and risk-off deleveraging.

I am in the middle of this spectrum. On one hand, I cannot ignore the 72% yoy jump in USDC circulation last year. On the other hand, I am concerned that the circulation of USDC is pegged to Bitcoin prices, as noted by the low single-digit sequential growth in Circle's reserve income in Q4 (vs double digit in Q3).

The other revenue segment is still small compared to the reserve income stream. This means that the top-line is highly exposed to the circulation of USDC and, to a lesser extent, interest rates.

I am cautiously bullish on Circle considering a timeframe of 12-18 months. Anything less than that is too uncertain to predict. I explain below why.

Q4 Overview

Circle’s core product is USDC (USD Coin), a U.S. dollar-pegged stablecoin that moves on blockchains. As seen below, this stablecoin trails Tether in terms of market cap:

However, the adoption of USDC last year was quite impressive. At the end of 2025, the USDC in circulation was $75–75.3 billion, up 72% yoy, outpacing the broader CFX stablecoin market. Given the decline in the overall crypto market in Q4, I found this growth rate quite impressive.

In terms of revenue generation, the main income stream comes from the interest on the reserve assets backing USDC. For reference, USDC is backed 1:1 by reserve assets. In Q4, the company reported $733 million in reserve income, up 69% yoy.

Wait a second, interest rates came down in the past year, from 4.48% in December 2024 down to 3.72% in Dec 2025.

How did revenue grow by 69% then?

The answer you’re looking for is volume. The company reported 72% yoy growth in USDC circulation at the end of last year.

Unsurprisingly, that’s a very similar growth rate to reserve income.

Now, sequentially, I wasn't particularly impressed with the reserve income growth. In Q3, the company reported $711M. That means that Q4 reserve income was up by just 3%. Peanuts, when compared to the sequential growth in Q3 of 12.1%. I will discuss more in the risk section.

The other revenue stream is grouped into the "other revenue" bucket in the company's financial reporting. That includes subscription and services (which have a recurring nature) and transaction revenue (which are mainly usage-based). In the last quarter, the company reported $37M in other revenue, and they guided $150–$170M for FY26. I wasn't particularly impressed with this guidance. Why?

Annualized, the $37M in Q4 represents $148M. That's pretty much the lower end of the guidance for "other revenue" this year. At the midpoint, we're talking about 8.1% yoy growth (vs the $148M annualized value). Call me crazy, but that's not a compelling growth story. That said, if the crypto market bounces back, management may upgrade that guidance, which brings me to my next point.

Circle Is Still A Beta On Crypto

The stock, along with the volume circulation of USDC, seems to correlate to the overall price swings of crypto, despite USDC being pegged to the dollar.

Let me explain.

As I said in the last section, the sequential growth between Q2 and Q3 last year was 12%. In comparison, the sequential growth between Q3 and Q4 was only 3%.

I am not surprised in the slightest. Take a look at the chart below showing the price change in Q4 of my favourite ETF proxy for Bitcoin: the iShares Bitcoin Trust ETF.

Please note that since the end of Q4, there has been another 20% haircut in IBIT.

Based on the above, I can conclude with a relatively high level of certainty that the circulation of USDC depends on the crypto market, which is mainly driven by Bitcoin. In my view, the more excitement there is in the crypto space (i.e., "investors" bidding up Bitcoin's price), the more USDC transactions happen. I think I am not alone with my hypothesis. The IMF states stablecoins are "currently mostly used for crypto trades."

The question now is whether Bitcoin can turn around in the near term. If it does, that should push up USDC circulation, which will naturally push the reserve income of Circle.

In my view, I don't think the lows in crypto are behind us. After Bitcoin's worst day since FTX earlier this month, the price failed to recover in a V-shaped style. In fact, just a few days back, Bitcoin was trading for $62k, confirming my thesis that the bounce on February 6 was just a dead cat bounce.

That said, looking at a 12-18 month timeframe, I have little to no doubts that risk will be back in the markets and Bitcoin will retest new highs again. I have some skin in the game with my thesis on the recovery of crypto, as I own shares in Ethereum's biggest public whale, BMNR.

Back to Circle and to my thesis that this stock is a beta on the overall crypto space, another point that favors my hypothesis is the post Q4 earnings rip. Some may think that the results were spectacular. For the argument I stated at the beginning of this section, I digress. Take a look at the crypto tape (1-D return) for February 25:

Crypto was up yesterday, with Bitcoin having the best day since the Feb 6 dead cat bounce. In my view, a good part of this outperformance was due to investors' risk appetite increasing in anticipation of Nvidia's blowout Q4 earnings.

In fact, in the last week, tech is back in the top 2 sectors by returns in the S&P 500 (a step change from the underperformance in the past 3 months), which is often a positive sign of the appetite for risk assets. Naturally, Bitcoin benefits in this risk-on environment.

Valuation

Versus the crypto-native peers, Circle's forward P/S ratio (6.2x) is roughly in line with Coinbase (6.7x) and far below Robinhood's 12.8x. Overall, I am not discontent with this ratio, given Circle's unique moat (i.e., USDC, the second-largest stablecoin by market cap).

Since the post IPO excitement, shares have significantly cooled off, although that doesn't mean that the lows are behind. For reference, Circle's IPO price on June 4 was $31/share. Today, the price is $83 after testing the $50 level a few weeks back.

Looking Ahead

In the near term, I am not planning to add this stock to my portfolio, especially after yesterday's rip. Overall, I don't think the lows in the crypto space are behind us, and I see further downside in H1 this year. I laid out the rationale in this article. That said, a broader market correction could still pressure Bitcoin, as investors deleverage and reduce risk in their portfolios.

Why would this be bad for the owner of the second-largest stablecoin?

As I've shown in this article, I strongly believe that the circulation of USDC is pegged to the overall crypto prices. This is reflected by the low single-digit sequential increase in reserve revenue in Q4 vs the double-digit qoq increase in Q3 last year. While some may believe this flatness is attributed to the 2 rate cuts in Q4, please be aware that the Q3 quarter was also pressured by a rate cut. Yet, it grew in the double digits.

That said, I think we may see a crypto recovery in the back half of the year, which should push up USDC circulation. In the near term, though, investor risk appetite in crypto is highly uncertain, which makes the outlook choppy. I think that's why management guided USDC to grow at 40% CAGR over a multi-year through-cycle (and not 40% this year):

Let me conclude with comments on our guidance for FY 2026. We do not give guidance on USDC circulation or growth. We are at the beginning of meaningful shifts in the global markets for money, and we expect both long-term growth and quarter-on-quarter variability. As previously noted, we would anticipate USDC to grow at a 40% CAGR over a multiyear through cycle.

As for the RLDC (Revenue Less Distribution Costs) margin, Q4 had a very decent 40% margin, after the company paid $461M in distribution, transaction, and other costs (up 52% yoy). It seems that the distribution costs scale with USDC circulation, which I believe is the main reason the guidance for FY26 assumes an RLDC margin between 38-40%.

Overall, I am cautiously bullish considering a multiyear timeframe, as I expect crypto prices to recover in the back half of the year. In the meantime, I would treat this stock with caution.

data.title: HP Q1 Earnings: Mr. Market's Short-Term Focus Presents Us An Opportunity
data.description:
Introduction

HP Inc. (HPQ), the diversified computer and related peripherals manufacturer, has been on my radar for quite some time now. I first wrote about it here on Seeking Alpha back in late 2022. Quite understandably, I never found the company particularly exciting given its significant exposure to largely commoditized products, lacking meaningful unique selling propositions. However, after HP shares had declined—to some extent understandably—against the backdrop of the 2025 tariffs to a level reflecting what I considered a reasonable margin of safety from a long-term investor's perspective, I turned cautiously bullish.

I never intended to own HP stock as part of my high-quality core portfolio but figured that at a price in the mid-$20s, a small position to the tune of 0.5% could be justified for my speculative satellite portfolio. At a free cash flow yield of more than 10% at the time of my last article, the company was already priced for (slow) terminal decline. Despite the already convincing valuation, however, I noted that I intended to approach the stock rather cautiously via out-of-the-money put options.

HP reported its results for the first quarter of fiscal 2026 on Tuesday after the bell. The shares reacted rather negatively immediately after the announcement but traded more or less sideways during yesterday's market hours. Nevertheless, HP stock declined to well under $20 since my last article, justifying a fresh look at the company.

HP's Q1 FY2026 Earnings: Operations Holding Up Well Despite Another Headwind

For the first quarter of fiscal 2026, HP Inc. reported non-GAAP earnings per share (EPS) of $0.81, well ahead of the latest consensus of $0.77 and up almost 10% year-over-year.

Net revenues came in slightly better than expected at $14.44 billion, up almost 7% year-over-year. In my view, this kind of top-line growth is rather reassuring for a company that is known to offer largely commoditized products, which suggests no particular pricing power. As illustrated in Figure 1, the boom period of the early 2020s is well behind us now, but HP's revenues are recovering slowly from the fiscal 2024 low.

Segment-wise, personal systems surprised positively with reassuring revenue growth of 11% year-over-year. HP benefitted from the weak U.S. dollar in Q1 but, even adjusting for currency growth, remained very solid at 9%. Volume-wise, both the consumer and the commercial personal systems segments remained resilient, with 14% and 11% growth year-over-year, respectively. Printing revenues—which represented 29% of consolidated net revenues in Q1—were down 2% year-over-year, or -3% in constant currency.

Turning back to HP's reported EPS, the significant adjustments—as illustrated by GAAP EPS of just $0.58, 25% less—are worth taking a closer look.

Litigation and amortization of intangible assets were responsible for $0.12 per share, but these are adjustments that I consider appropriate. I am a bit on the fence with regard to the ongoing adjustment of restructuring charges, which were rather high in Q1 FY26 at $0.14 per share. By comparison, the company reported restructuring charges of $0.07 and $0.11 per share in Q3 and Q4 of FY25, respectively. In view of tariff-related adaptation of HP's manufacturing and assembling footprint, these additional expenditures make sense, of course, as does treating them as one-offs. However, I keep an eye on these costs and expect them to abate sooner rather than later. At the same time, I look at HP stock's valuation mainly through the lens of free cash flow, which automatically considers such expenses.

More importantly than earnings adjustments, let's take a look at HP's margin profile. The company was never particularly strong from a gross profitability standpoint, which itself is a key argument why I would never want to own a significant position in HP stock. Gross margin averaged 20.6% between Q1 of fiscal 2020 and Q4 of fiscal 2025, whereas in the recently concluded quarter, HP reported a margin of just 19.6%, down 140 bps year-over-year or down 60 bps sequentially:

In view of the tariffs, but also given the sharply risen memory prices, the ongoing decline in gross profitability is understandable, but nonetheless requires a careful look given the company's generally limited headroom. However, HP's management is maintaining profitability as best it can, as evidenced by meaningful savings in other operating expenses (R&D and selling, general, and administrative expenses), which declined by 61 basis points year-over-year in Q1.

At the same time, I would not go so far as to conclude that management is underinvesting in terms of R&D and advertising: HP continues to invest approximately 2.5% to 3.0% of its net revenues in research and development. Advertising expenses aren't disclosed on a quarterly basis, but as per HP's fiscal 2025 10-K (p. 58), the company spent 1.2% of net revenues on advertising on average over the past three years. In fiscal 2025, related expenses were even slightly higher, at 1.3% of net revenues.

Taken together, HP's operating margin contracted by roughly 40 bps in Q1, to 6.9%, not including restructuring and litigation-related expenses. In view of the current headwinds, I think that HP's profitability is holding up well and management was quite quick to implement the necessary mitigation steps. Of course, however, it will take time before they become fully effective.

On the earnings call, management announced expanded pricing actions but also additional company-wide cost reductions, so it will be interesting to see how especially the former impacts demand going forward. While a near-term deceleration is a reasonable expectation, the company should benefit over the longer term as the pricing pressures abate eventually when memory supply ticks up and/or AI data center demand turns out to be weaker than currently anticipated. Shares of Samsung, SK hynix Inc. (HXSC.F), Sandisk Corp. (SNDK) and the like can be watched as a barometer of sorts.

In terms of operating cash flow, I was pleased to see HP having generated $383 million in Q1 of fiscal 2026, in line with the prior year period. Capital expenditures were down more than 20%, translating to reported free cash flow of $175 million. Of course, the timing of supplier and customer payments can throw off quarterly cash flows quite significantly. Hence, I prefer to look at free cash flow from a full-year perspective.

For fiscal 2026, management expects free cash flow of around $2.8 billion to $3.0 billion, but this does not include stock-based compensation—a significant position in HP's cash flow statement. As the eventually issued performance shares must be repurchased with actual cash and HP remains committed to returning roughly all of its free cash flow to shareholders over time, I prefer to deduct stock-based compensation, or SBC, as if it were an immediate cash expense. After this adjustment, free cash flow should come in at roughly $2.4 billion. This translates to an adjusted free cash flow margin of approximately 4.3%, thereby indicating reasonably good cash flow conversion, especially for a company with significant inventories.

One aspect worth highlighting in the context of the gap between operating and cash profitability is HP's interest expenses (currently 12% of GAAP operating earnings) and, as a consequence, its debt.

The company continues to carry significant debt on its balance sheet, although I maintain it is well-staggered in terms of maturities (updated profile in Figure 4) and that net debt has declined meaningfully from its high reached in the first quarter of fiscal 2023 (Figure 5), but has remained largely unchanged since the end of that year.

While I certainly appreciate management's commitment to prioritizing cash returns to shareholders in view of no meaningful internal investment opportunities, the conservative investor in me, of course, would prefer further deleveraging. Indeed, management noted on the earnings call that debt maturing in fiscal 2026 will be paid down and maturities in fiscal 2027 could be addressed as well.

Against this backdrop, and provided that demand does not deteriorate significantly, I see no reason why HP should not be able to maintain its favorable standing with the rating agencies. Moody's, for example, last reviewed HP's long-term rating in September 2025 and maintained its Baa2 rating with a stable outlook.

That said, and striking a somewhat more opportunistic tone, in view of the investment-grade credit rating, a leverage ratio of well under 3x adjusted free cash flow, and the compelling valuation of HP shares, I am quite happy that management continues to repurchase stock while maintaining (and even growing) the dividend. Also worth noting is that, unlike some companies in the technology sector where performance shares issued are offsetting most (or even all) buybacks, the number of HP shares outstanding has declined significantly in recent years:

Conclusion: Resilient Operations, Yet HP Stock Is Priced For Decline

HP Inc. reported reassuring results for the first quarter of fiscal 2026. Demand for the company's AI PCs was strong, and the Windows 11 refresh cycle remains a tailwind worth highlighting. In my view, management continues to do a great job at maintaining core profitability while navigating what I view as a pretty challenging environment (tariffs, sharply risen memory prices). At the same time, the necessary investments in research and development as well as advertising are being maintained.

While management expects to hit full-year adjusted EPS guidance for fiscal 2026 near the low end, free cash flow guidance was maintained. Therefore, and despite the generous dividend, the company should still be in a position to buy back shares worth several hundred million dollars while also addressing upcoming maturities.

Over the long term, demand in HP's Personal Systems division is likely to remain solid due to the expected significantly higher resource intensity of Windows 12 (rumored for 2027). At the same time, I continue to anticipate a sustained decline in HP's printer segment revenues, coupled with a (slow) decline in profitability.

Taken together, the Q1 FY2026 earnings report left me rather positive, and my longer-term view on HP Inc. remains constructive as well.

At the same time, the valuation of HP shares based on a discounted cash flow sensitivity analysis (Figure 7) suggests that the market continues to view the company as being in terminal decline. With a discount rate (cost of equity) of 9%, HP could see its free cash flow decline by 3.5% per year for the company to be fairly valued at $18.2 today. In my view, this represents a rather meaningful margin of safety, at least from the perspective of an investor with a multi-year horizon.

To further support my point, I'd like to draw your attention to Figure 8.

Hypothetically, HP Inc. could go out of business in fiscal 2045, i.e., after 20 years. At the required rate of return mentioned above, but assuming a slightly slower decline rate of 2.5% per annum until the cessation of business operations in FY45, HP shares would be worth $19.5. In other words, with a current share price of $18.2, HP Inc. could cease operations after only 16 years to achieve the above-mentioned return of 9.0% per annum. This assumes, of course, that free cash flow—notably including stock-based compensation as a cash expense—is returned to shareholders via dividends or share buybacks. Debt is not taken into account in this highly simplified thought experiment, but bear in mind its significant decline in value over the years.

To end on a more optimistic note, if HP continues to navigate the current environment just reasonably well (as it currently does, in my view), it will likely be able to maintain free cash flow of at least $2.5 billion for the foreseeable future. Given that the shares are currently trading at an adjusted free cash flow yield of 14% and a forward P/E ratio of only 6.2, buybacks are very efficient. The market views the company as facing significant challenges, so returns should be very attractive if HP performs only slightly better than currently expected. I, therefore, remain constructive on HP stock and look forward to further increasing my recently initiated position.

Thank you very much for reading my latest article. Whether you agree or disagree with my conclusions, I always welcome your opinion and feedback in the comments below. And if there's anything I should improve or expand on in future articles, drop me a line as well. As always, please consider this article only as a first step in your own due diligence.

data.title: SoFi's Reset Could Be A Generational Entry Point
data.description:
The reason SoFi Technologies (SOFI) declined from its high $20s isn't because the company missed something on the operations front. The reason is much simpler: the market has decided it no longer wants to pay up for a fintech story that gets financed on common equity. My buy rating on SoFi last year outperformed the market, delivering a 68% return in under 12 months versus roughly 27% for the broader market over the same period.

When a company's stock declines from $33 to $19 in a matter of months, there is a natural temptation to point to macro forces, interest rates, rotation, short sellers, or some other vague risk-off market environment as the culprit. Those things matter too. The most straightforward explanation is simply that the company asked its shareholders to pay for the next phase of the company's growth, twice.

I'm not dismissing the company's strategic decision to raise $3.2 billion in capital. If you believe in SoFi's ability to compound into a scaled financial utility with tech-like margins, you want a balance sheet that can absorb a credit downturn and still have cash left over to sign partners. The problem is timing and messaging. Issuing a large equity offering after a massive run is a clear signal to investors that management is prioritizing optionality for the corporation, not scarcity of shares. That's rational. That's exactly how you destroy a company's ability to negotiate a high multiple for its equity.

What’s more interesting to me than the drawdown itself is what it says about the market’s tolerance.
